text: I haven’t checked into Julia development for a while and am working in music, games and animation: is it possible or straightforward to build .exe’s yet? Thank you.
the answer is probably no depending on how "straightforward" you want

elements.text: the answer is probably no depending on how "straightforward" you want

text: Ideally by sending one command like in Unity engine - but how many steps does it take now to build and julia exe for win 10 for example? thank you.
well, you can pack a exe with julia itself, all julia dependencies and scripts in a .exe but I assumed you mean statically compile to a binary

elements.text: well, you can pack a exe with julia itself, all julia dependencies and scripts in a .exe but I assumed you mean statically compile to a binary

text:
If you’re making a game, the extra overhead of bundling the whole Julia runtime probably won’t be all that significant. It’s a constant offset. 

I’d look into PackageCompiler.jl

elements.text:
If you’re making a game, the extra overhead of bundling the whole Julia runtime probably won’t be all that significant. It’s a constant offset. 

I’d look into PackageCompiler.jl

text: Thank you
except PackageCompiler != no JIT right? it's just type inference is baked into system image

elements.text: except PackageCompiler != no JIT right? it's just type inference is baked into system image

text: I just want to try my hand at a text based game
How large would an exe be with runtime?
helloworld is Order of ~100MB last time someone checked

elements.text: helloworld is Order of ~100MB last time someone checked

text: I heard that go also has to do the same
Omg :hushed:
Didn’t expect that
exactly, so maybe don't do game development with Julia just yet

elements.text: exactly, so maybe don't do game development with Julia just yet

text: Is this something people are working on actively to reduce?
not with high priority I think

elements.text: not with high priority I think

text:
> except PackageCompiler != no JIT right? it's just type inference is baked into system image (edited)
Depends on if you add precompile statements or not. Often a test suite is enough to statically compile most of the methodinstances into your sysimage and remove most or all of the JIT. Other times, you might need something more agressive. It depends.

elements.text: except PackageCompiler != no JIT right? it's just type inference is baked into system image (edited)

Depends on if you add precompile statements or not. Often a test suite is enough to statically compile most of the methodinstances into your sysimage and remove most or all of the JIT. Other times, you might need something more agressive. It depends.

text: I’m assuming python and c can build smaller exe for hello world? And Julia is supposed to be competing in that space + education. Surprising that this is not a priority.

> Is this something people are working on actively to reduce?
Yes, there is active work happening on this.

elements.text: Is this something people are working on actively to reduce?
Yes, there is active work happening on this.

text: Great :+1:
Keep in mind, that 100mb or whatever is a constant offset. It's gigatic for a hello world program, but if you make a large game, it's not that unreasonable.

elements.text: Keep in mind, that 100mb or whatever is a constant offset. It's gigatic for a hello world program, but if you make a large game, it's not that unreasonable.

text: Mason can you point me to an active work on this? the consensus I've been hearing is that because how we have to pack all Julia's type system and dynamic mechanism into it, there's no trivial way to compile small binary programs

elements.text: Mason can you point me to an active work on this? the consensus I've been hearing is that because how we have to pack all Julia's type system and dynamic mechanism into it, there's no trivial way to compile small binary programs

text: and I don't know there's active development specifically targeting this, if you have a WIP PR or and issue as pointer that would be great

elements.text: and I don't know there's active development specifically targeting this, if you have a WIP PR or and issue as pointer that would be great

text:
> there's no trivial way to compile small binary programs
This is plain incorrect. Julia already has a compiler that can make small, static JIT-free binaries, it's just specialized for GPU compilation. GPUCompiler.jl does this today and works. Julian Samaroo and a few other people are working on repurposing this stuff for CPU code generation

elements.text: there's no trivial way to compile small binary programs

This is plain incorrect. Julia already has a compiler that can make small, static JIT-free binaries, it's just specialized for GPU compilation. GPUCompiler.jl does this today and works. Julian Samaroo and a few other people are working on repurposing this stuff for CPU code generation

text: It looks like according to <https://github.com/tshort/StaticCompiler.jl/pull/42> they have decided to use the StaticCompiler.jl repo as the home for the code.

elements.text: It looks like according to
they have decided to use the StaticCompiler.jl repo as the home for the code.

text: Here's a recent writeup from Julian discussing the situation and approach: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rLpZf-HK6b9uYPDT_piUza4LUhtIrLbUftGa_YaXGKQ/edit>

elements.text: Here's a recent writeup from Julian discussing the situation and approach:

text: compiling to GPU is somewhat different. If you have a computational kernel you want to compile to CUDA, that is specialized thing

elements.text: compiling to GPU is somewhat different. If you have a computational kernel you want to compile to CUDA, that is specialized thing

text: a general piece of Julia code that needs LLVM and involves dynamic parts shouldn't be seen as a GPU number crunching kernel function

elements.text: a general piece of Julia code that needs LLVM and involves dynamic parts shouldn't be seen as a GPU number crunching kernel function

text: I don't think there's currently any mechanism to isolate what's needed from what's not in order to produce a small static binary. Classic example being helloworld

elements.text: I don't think there's currently any mechanism to isolate what's needed from what's not in order to produce a small static binary. Classic example being helloworld

text:
> compiling to GPU is somewhat different. If you have a computational kernel you 
> want to compile to CUDA, that is specialized thing
It's really not. GPUCompiler.jl mostly just replaces some primitives with GPU friendly primitives and then hands off the LLVM IR to LLVM's CUDA backend. What's needed to repurpose this is to essentially just change the backend from the CUDA backend to the CPU one.

> a general piece of Julia code that needs LLVM and involves dynamic parts shouldn't be seen as a GPU number crunching kernel function
Sure, dynamic code will need the julia runtime. OF course it does. But if you write statically inferrable code, then you can bypass the runtime alltogether

elements.text:
compiling to GPU is somewhat different. If you have a computational kernel you 
want to compile to CUDA, that is specialized thing

It's really not. GPUCompiler.jl mostly just replaces some primitives with GPU friendly primitives and then hands off the LLVM IR to LLVM's CUDA backend. What's needed to repurpose this is to essentially just change the backend from the CUDA backend to the CPU one.
a general piece of Julia code that needs LLVM and involves dynamic parts shouldn't be seen as a GPU number crunching kernel function
Sure, dynamic code will need the julia runtime. OF course it does. But if you write statically inferrable code, then you can bypass the runtime alltogether

text: I agree, but I'm saying that I have not seen any demo/ WIP stuff that does the isolation / bypass or claim this is something being worked on as 1st priority.

elements.text: I agree, but I'm saying that I have not seen any demo/ WIP stuff that does the isolation / bypass or claim this is something being worked on as 1st priority.

text:
There's also an intermediate stage where you need the dynamic dispatch machinery, but don't need runtime code generation. Hence, Julian has a PR open that will separate LibJulia from the runtime codegen machinery.

Hence, we'll be able to have dynamic dispatch in a lighter binary so long as the needed code is generated AOT

elements.text:
There's also an intermediate stage where you need the dynamic dispatch machinery, but don't need runtime code generation. Hence, Julian has a PR open that will separate LibJulia from the runtime codegen machinery.

Hence, we'll be able to have dynamic dispatch in a lighter binary so long as the needed code is generated AOT

text: I guess I just wanted to be clear that it is not something we have even a demo ready, for <@UAF4RHDFC> who's new to the language and doing something anew. We've come a long way but this is not close to production ready so I didn't want to lure someone in and disappoint them.

text: PackageCompiler *already works* and I don't see how it's not appropriate for making a game if someone wanted to try. Binary size and full static compilation are not super hard constraints on games

elements.text: PackageCompiler
already works
and I don't see how it's not appropriate for making a game if someone wanted to try. Binary size and full static compilation are not super hard constraints on games

text: Compilation would be my last concern about making a game in julia, personally. Much more pressing is just the lack of ecosystem, assets, community and tooling for game development.

elements.text: Compilation would be my last concern about making a game in julia, personally. Much more pressing is just the lack of ecosystem, assets, community and tooling for game development.

text: I guess that will be up for them to decide since I think they're new to coding and used mature tool like Unity and other tools before not sure how much they want to sink into julia just making a text game. If they are game engine developer trying to make a new engine or use Julia as their scripting language, I wouldn't worry as much.

elements.text: I guess that will be up for them to decide since I think they're new to coding and used mature tool like Unity and other tools before not sure how much they want to sink into julia just making a text game. If they are game engine developer trying to make a new engine or use Julia as their scripting language, I wouldn't worry as much.

text: Yeah, I don't mean to make it sound like Julia is all rosy for making games. I think it can be a great language for it, but it'll require making a lot of your own tools and thinking hard about problems that the community hasn't thought much about. I just wanted to say that static compilation isn't really going to be your biggest concern.

elements.text: Yeah, I don't mean to make it sound like Julia is all rosy for making games. I think it can be a great language for it, but it'll require making a lot of your own tools and thinking hard about problems that the community hasn't thought much about. I just wanted to say that static compilation isn't really going to be your biggest concern.
